tracks.title: String Quintet in E, Op. 11, No. 5, "Minuet"
tracks.performer: Orpheus Chamber Orchestra

soundsnips.text: Although he was successful as a composer and musician for most of his lifetime, Boccherini lived the end of his life in poverty and he was given a pauper's burial.

Boccherini was almost thrown out of a window after he accused the Prince of the Asturias (a region in northern Spain) of not being a true musician. The prince's wife begged him not to do it and Boccherini's life was spared.
Compositions for ensembles like the string quintet -- two violins, viola, and two cellos -- began to appear around the mid-18th century.

Instead of designating a full-time conductor, members of the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra take turns assuming the role. Their leaderless leadership is so inspiring that they have been selected to give management seminars at large corporations (such as Kraft Foods).
The "minuet" was one of the most popular dances during the Baroque era.
There's hardly a fancy-shmancy dinner scene in movie history without this track. This trend seems to have started with a scene in the "The Ladykillers," a 1955 film starring Alec Guinness.
Due to his own extreme talent as a cellist, Boccherini often wrote rich, ornate parts for the cello in his compositions.
Boccherini produced most of his work in the latter half of the 18th century.
Boccherini is considered a master of chamber music -- he wrote over 100 quintets, around 100 quartets, and 100 other chamber works.

tracks.title: Harp Concerto in Bb, Op. 4, No. 6, HWV 294
tracks.performer: Academy of St. Martin in the Fields; Iona Brown, conductor; Marisa Robles, harp

soundsnips.text: Although Handel had a natural talent for music, his father thought music to be an impractical career choice and tried to persuade his son to quit. Handel kept his passion under wraps by sneaking up to the attic to practice his clavichord when his dad wasn't around.

While performing with the Hamburg Opera Orchestra, Handel refused to give up his harpsichord seat to fellow composer Johann Mattheson. To settle the dispute, they agreed to a duel. The button on Handel's coat deflected Mattheson's blade during the fight, saving Handel's life as well as their friendship.
Handel on the value of his music: "I should be sorry if I only entertained them. I wished to make them better."
Here, the harp is instructed to play "obbligato," a term that describes the harp solo as a vital part of the concerto.
Listen to the performance of Spanish harpist Marisa Robles. She is one of the most widely known harpist of the 20th and 21st centuries. Many have written pieces especially for her.
The harpsichord serves a purely accompanying -- or "continuo" -- function in this concerto.

The best word to describe Handel is "cosmopolitan." He contributed to almost every music genre of his time and he traveled extensively throughout Europe to incorporate the best the world had to offer in his works.
In 1759, at least 3,000 people attended Handel's funeral at Westminster Abbey, London.
Handel composed the bulk of his work during the first half of the 18th century.
Handel is probably most known for the "Hallelujah" chorus of his "Messiah" choral work. However, he achieved celebrity status during his lifetime due to his mastery of opera, not religious music.

tracks.title: Divertimento in D (Compilation)
tracks.performer: Academy of St. Martin in the Fields; Sir Neville Marriner, conductor

soundsnips.text: Mozart was a Freemason. He eventually became a Master Mason (a fairly high rank within the society) and persuaded both his father and Franz Joseph Haydn to join the fraternal organization.

Everyone knows him by one name, but he was christened with five: Joannes Chrysostomus Wolfgangus Theophilus Mozart. (Wolfgangus was the name of his maternal grandfather and Theophilus becomes "Amadeus" in Latin.)

This track is a compilation of smaller pieces of Mozart's work featured on the album, "Mozart: Rarities and Surprises." It isn't an official "Divertimento" but it captures the tone and quality of one!
When you hear the sound of the French horn, do you immediately think, "let the hunt begin"? Well, you should. Early versions of horn were once used by hunters to signal just that.
Sir Neville Marriner, the conductor of this performance, also helped arrange the music for the universally loved Mozart biopic, "Amadeus" (1984).
If you think the flute and oboe sound like they're talking to each other, you're right. It's a compositional technique based on communication called "imitative call and response."
Haydn on Mozart: "I swear before God and as an honest man, that your son is the greatest composer known to me, either in person or by reputation."
A "divertimento" is a chamber work that is considered light and amusing. Think "diversion."
Mozart composed all of his work during his brief, 35-year existence in the latter half of the 18th century.
Mozart is probably the most known and loved classical composer of all time. His style is regarded as a prime example of the Viennese Classical idiom.

tracks.title: Concerto for Mandolin in C, RV425
tracks.performer: Rolf Lislevand, mandolin

soundsnips.text: Vivaldi was known as "the red priest" because of his red hair.

Although Vivaldi attained fame during his lifetime, he died in poverty and remained virtually unknown for centuries. Vivaldi's legacy was finally resurrected in the mid-20th century, when new recordings achieved substantial acclaim.
Vivaldi was a pretty confident fellow. He wrote this across the top of an opera score: "If you don't like this, I'll stop writing music."

The second movement of Vivaldi's mandolin concerto is much slower in tempo. Many three-movement works follow this tempo scheme. The outer movements are energetic while the middle movement is often reflective in tone.
Besides the mandolin, soloist Rolf Lislevand plays a number of instruments that range from archaic to practically unknown -- lute, baroque guitar, vihuela and theorbo.
Historically, the concerto format relies heavily on dialogue created between the featured soloist (here, the mandolin) and the rest of the orchestra. Listen to the relationship!

Throughout the 1730s, half-sisters Anna Giro (an aspiring mezzo-soprano) and Paolina Giro (a nurse) traveled with and cared for Vivaldi. There are rumors of a romantic relationship between Vivaldi and Anna, however no evidence exists to prove anything beyond a professional relationship.
Vivaldi composed the bulk of his work during the first half of the 18th century.
Vivaldi is considered as one of the masters of the Baroque instrumental concerto. He composed at least 500 concertos over the course of his career.

tracks.title: Octet in F, Op. 128: III. Allegretto
tracks.performer: Consortium Classicum; Dieter Koecker, conductor

soundsnips.text: Due to childhood smallpox, Ries could only see out of one eye.
Ries was one of Beethoven's piano students.
The third movement is marked "allegretto," which means it is to be played a little faster than "andante" but a little slower than "allegro."

Dieter Klocker is considered to be one of the finest German clarinetists of his generation. He's credited with unearthing forgotten masters of that transitional time between the Classical and Romantic eras.
This piece is a work for eight (octet, get it?) instruments: piano, bassoon, horn, clarinet, bass, cello, viola and violin.

To say Ries' family was musically inclined would be an understatement: his father was a violin prodigy, his aunt was a court soprano, and his younger brother, Hubert, would later become the director of the Berlin Philharmonic Society.

Besides his compositions, Ries was a celebrated pianist. "The Harmonicon," an English journal, had this to say about one of his performances: "His hand is powerful, and his execution is certain, - often surprising. But his playing is most distinguished from that of all others by its romantic wildness."
Ries wrote the bulk of his compositions around the beginning of the 19th century.
After he retired, Ries collaborated with F. G. Wegeler to write "Biographical Notices of Beethoven," which is one of the most important biographies on Beethoven ever written.

tracks.title: Waltz in Ab, Op. 69, No. 1, "L'adieu"
tracks.performer: Garrick Ohlsson, piano

soundsnips.text: Chopin wrote this "Farewell Waltz" for painter Maria Wodzinska, to whom he was once engaged.
Chopin's marriage to Maria would never be. Her family thought he was an unfit suitor due to his questionable health. He would wrestle with a variety of physical ailments for the rest of his life.
Chopin: "Simplicity is the final achievement...it is simplicity that emerges in all its charm as the ultimate crowning reward of art. "
"L'adieu" has a nostalgic affect that Chopin explores by re-stating the opening melody with a reflective mood before bringing closure to the piece.
Pianist Garrick Ohlsson once told the Associated Press the hardest part of touring is the formal post-concert receptions where "people are too nice to you."
In the 19th and 20th centuries, the piano became a popular piece of furniture in European and American homes. As amateur music-making took off, the sheet music industry emerged.
Pianist Glenn Gould (who was equally famous for his piano mastery as his eccentricities) on Chopin: ''Chopin, Schubert and Liszt had no idea of how to write for the piano.''
This piece of Chopin's work was not published during his lifetime. Also, even though it is titled as a "waltz," it serves a musical function rather than providing a dance tune.

Chopin had a long relationship with novelist George Sand (who defied cultural conventions by taking up activities that, at the time, were reserved for men -- she wore trousers, smoked cigar and pursued intellectualism).
Chopin composed the bulk of his work during the first half of the 19th century.
Chopin is considered as one of the most significant composers of the Romantic era. His piano works are staples of the instrument's repertoire.

tracks.title: Concerto for Piano and Violin in G, Op. 17: III. Rondo
tracks.performer: London Mozart Players; Howard Shelly, piano

soundsnips.text: Hummel was known as selfish and arrogant until he married -- then he became a committed family man and patient teacher.
Hummel developed a fluency for the violin and piano at a very young age and studied with Mozart in Vienna.
Hummel to one of his pupils: "Enjoy the world, while you attempt to provide it enjoyment...never forget this watchword: Moderation."

This return to a familiar musical melody, here played by the piano and subsequently the violin, is a defining characteristic of rondo form. It will return once more at the end to "round" off the form.
Pianist Howard Shelly's first performance was a unique event -- not only was he 10 years old at the time, it was broadcasted on BBC Television.
This piece is considered a "double concerto" because not one but two instruments are spotlighted: the violin and the piano.

Hummel was a pioneer of music copyright law. He and his sometimes-friend Beethoven submitted a manifesto to the German government to enact legislation that would protect their work. In the document, they claimed German music publishers were "getting fat by robbing without penalty their neighbors' property."

If you're wondering what "op." stands for in many classical pieces, you're not alone. It stands for "opus" and serves to give a reference number to the works of each composer. However, they are not numbered chronologically. Think of them as an ID number!
Hummel was a Classical era composer. He produced his compositions from the very late 18th century through the beginning of the 19th century.
Beyond his compositions, Hummel was one of Europe's most famous pianists during the 1820s and 1830s. Those were also the last two decades of his life.

tracks.title: String Sonata No. 1 in G
tracks.performer: Hungarian Virtuosi; Tamas Benedek, conductor

soundsnips.text: In 1829, Rossini retired from composition at the age of 37. He was at the height of his career, but the sheer physical and emotional exhaustion he suffered during his career proved too much. Although he would eventually write other pieces, he would never indulge his fans with another opera.
Which is more impressive, that Rossini wrote this piece in three days or that he wrote it when he was 12 years old? Because both are true!
Rossini on Wagner: "Mr. Wagner has beautiful moments but bad quarters of an hour."
Sound familiar? That's because sonatas have multiple recurring themes. Reintroducing a theme -- such as this one, from its beginning -- is a typical composition device in sonatas.
Tamas Benedek, conductor of the Hungarian Virtuosi Chamber Orchestra, studied the violin for twelve years before switching to conducting.
The double-bass, or "contrabasso," is an instrument that is most commonly found in full orchestras. Listen as Rossini uses the double-bass to expand the range of the ensemble.

Beethoven lauded Rossini's "The Barber of Seville" but warned him not to compose anything but comic opera. Rossini tried to laugh it off but, privately, he was deeply wounded and the comment would haunt him.
Rossini wrote his compositions during the first half of the 19th century.
Rossini's contemporaries considered him to be the greatest Italian composer of his time -- and he thoroughly enjoyed all the wealth, popularity and influence it granted him.

tracks.title: Symphony in Bb, MH 82
tracks.performer: Lausanne Chamber Orchestra; Christian Zacharias, conductor

soundsnips.text: As a boy, Michael sang for the St. Stephen's Cathedral choir, and what a choir boy he was! They say he had a singing range of three octaves.

One of the monks at the Abbey of St. Peter in Salzburg described Michael as quiet, discreet and modest. "Drink and gambling were far removed from him," said the monk. "Moderation in thinking, speaking, even in judging other musical works, were what made him beloved and valued."
The final movement is to be played "allegro assai," a tempo indication meaning "very fast."
The Lausanne Chamber Orchestra is comprised of 42 musicians -- this corresponds to the number of musicians Mozart required in his symphonies.
Listen as additional instruments repeat a similar theme: the first is stated by the violins, the second adds a horn and, on the third, enters cello and bass. Each addition enlivens the same phrase.
He may not have been as famous as his brother, but Michael Haydn gained significant fame within a particular genre -- church music.
Michael Haydn composed most of his works during the latter half of the 18th century.
Michael was the younger brother of the obviously more popular Franz Joseph Haydn.

tracks.title: Where the Rainbow Ends Suite, No. 1b: Will o' the Wisp
tracks.performer: Northern Sinfonia of England; Richard Hickox, conductor

soundsnips.text: Quilter was frequently ill throughout his life because of a large variety of physical and mental ailments -- from stomach

Quilter sometimes felt embarrassed by his family's wealth. In a letter to a friend, he wrote: "I have the English rich upper-middle-class blood in my veins too much, I'm not strong enough to fight it."

Quilter: "I am glad to say I can appreciate any kind of music which is sincere and vital - from Bach to a good ragtime. I enjoy immensely the music of Patience, and can also keenly relish Stravinsky's Petrushka."

This composition is "incidental music" -- meaning it was designed to accompany a written play. This song was written for "Where The Rainbow Ends," an extremely popular children's play that opened in 1911.
The conductor of this piece is Richard Hickox. He was known for championing the works of his native land by traveling around the world to conduct the compositions of British composers.
The source of the strummed chords is the harp -- an instrument that's been around for millennia. Engravings depicting harps have been found on tombs dating as far back as 4000 BCE.

The "Will o' the Wisp" is a character within this piece's accompanying play who serves as a guardian of children. During this song, fairies and other forest creatures dance along a riverbank at Will's request.
Quilter wrote most of his songs during the first half of the 20th century.
Quilter was most known for producing English "art songs," which are pieces that feature the human voice with a piano or orchestra accompaniment.

tracks.title: Bolero
tracks.performer: Montreal Symphony Orchestra; Charles Dutoit, conductor

soundsnips.text: In 1929, Ravel was commissioned by a WWI veteran (who had lost his right arm in the war) to write a piano concerto for one hand.

At the end of his life, Ravel suffered from a devastating neurological condition called frontotemporal dementia -- or Pick's Disease -- which causes compulsive, repetitious behaviors. Some neurologists have suggested the composition of "Bolero" was an early sign of the illness.
Ravel on "Bolero": "I have written only one masterpiece. Alas, it contains no music."
Music historians describe "Bolero" as the longest-sustained crescendo in orchestral history, as the piece only rises in volume and intensity.
In 2011, conductor Charles Dutoit held talks with cultural officials in both the North and South Koreas to plan for an inter-Korean youth orchestra.
What sounds like an oboe, but more sultry? Here, you're hearing the "oboe d'amore," or "oboe of love." It's slightly larger than the standard oboe and produces a less assertive tone.
Due to unfavorable comparisons and controversy in the press, the relationship between contemporaries Debussy and Ravel was civil at best.
"Bolero" served as background music for a steamy scene in the 1979 film "10" starring Bo Derek and Dudley Moore.
In 1917, Ravel's mother died and his artistic output immediately suffered. It is said that his relationship with his mother was the most significant one in his life.
Ravel produced some of his most significant works during the first three decades of the 20th century.
Ravel is known for producing extremely expressive, imaginative works that fused exotic inspirations with a decidedly French foundation.

tracks.title: Rhapsody In Blue
tracks.performer: London Symphony Orchestra; Mitch Miller, conductor; David Golub, piano

soundsnips.text: Gershwin suffered from poor health for most of his life. He ultimately died of an inoperable brain tumor in 1937 at only 38 years old.

Gershwin dropped out of high school to pursue a musical career. His first job was as a "song plugger" for a musical publishing firm. He made $15 per week promoting the firm by playing and singing songs for performers.
Gershwin on marriage: "Why should I limit myself to only one woman when I can have as many women as I want?"
Scored for piano and orchestra, this piece is reminiscent of a concerto, although not explicitly labeled as one. There are many sections, such as this one, where the piano has an extended solo.

This recording of "Rhapsody In Blue" is considered to be more "accurate" than most. Conductor Mitch Miller was himself a friend of Gershwin and made subtle suggestions to make it more closely resemble what Gershwin intended.
That buzzing sound is produced by inserting a special device -- known as a "harmon mute" -- into the bell of a trumpet.

They say "Rhapsody In Blue" was written in less than a month. The bandleader who commissioned the work from Gershwin made a premature announcement (that was published in the local paper), which led to its rushed schedule.
Most of Gershwin's compositions were written during the 1920s and 1930s.

By the age of 30, Gershwin was the most famous composer of concert and popular music in America. "Rhapsody In Blue" and "American in Paris" remain some of the most widely known, and loved, compositions ever penned.

tracks.title: Powder Her Face, Op. 14: Selections
tracks.performer: National Youth Orchestra of Great Britain; Paul Daniel, conductor

soundsnips.text: While attempting to compose an orchestral version of modern techno music, Ades got so involved with his writing that he thought he was having a heart attack and checked himself into a local hospital.
Ades' mother is an expert on Surrealist art and his father is a linguist.
Ades: "No one has the final word. No one exhausts the possibilities."
Hear how the trumpets oppose the rhythmic pulse of the piece? This is what's known as a "syncopation" of rhythm.
Founded in 1947, the National Youth Orchestra of Great Britain was created for exceptionally talented musicians between the ages of 13 and 19.
The metallic percussion sound is being created by the "hi-hat," which is a pedal-operated set of cymbals.
"Powder Her Face" is an opera based on the controversial (and sexually graphic) events surrounding the divorce of the Duchess and Duke of Argyll in 1963. It's not for the faint of heart.
He's often called classical music's "savior," "messiah" or even its "new Mozart." However, Ades finds the enthusiasm distasteful and is wary of media coverage.
Ades work is known for its color, vivid expressionism and eclectic influences (tango, avant-garde, and even techno).

tracks.title: Valse-Intermezzo for Strings in E minor, H. 17
tracks.performer: BBC National Orchestra of Wales; Richard Hickox, conductor

soundsnips.text: Although highly respected as a composer, Bridge was thought of as a harsh conductor that was exacting and tactless when directing musicians.
The compositions Bridge wrote during WWI have a dark, aggressive tone. Historians say this reflected the composer's moral objection to war as he was an ardent pacifist.
That shimmery effect is called a "trill," which is created by rapidly alternating between two notes.
The BBC National Orchestra of Wales began in 1928 as a smaller ensemble called the Cardiff Station Orchestra.
That low sustained drone is produced by the bow of the double-bass. Listen next as it changes to pizzicato (plucking of the strings).
Bridge wrote the bulk of his compositions during the first few decades of the 20th century.
Bridge is perhaps most known as the teacher of Benjamin Britten, who is also regarded as a great composer of the 20th century.

tracks.title: Ekitundu Ekisooka
tracks.performer: Kronos Quartet

soundsnips.text: Tamusuza studied composition in Belfast, Northern Ireland, where he learned Celtic composition. Some of his subsequent works display those characteristics.

The high-pitched chirping in the background is produced by a string harmonic. String harmonics are dictated by physics, meaning they sound properly only when the performer divides the string into the proper ratio. Science!

The Kronos Quartet is known for breaking classical stereotypes -- they perform as if they're playing rock (head-banging enthusiasm, etc.) and they dress much more informally you'd expect from chamber musicians.

Percussion in a string quartet? Now there's something you don't hear everyday. The members of the Kronos Quartet are creating these sounds by striking their hands against the wood of their instruments.
This track was recorded by the Kronos Quartet for the group's "Pieces of Africa" album, which was on Billboard's "World Albums" chart for 15 weeks in 1992.
Tamusuza is a contemporary composer. Most of his works were written in the late 20th century.
Tamusuza is Ugandan and uses his heritage to blend traditional African styles with Western classical techniques.

tracks.title: Summa, for Strings
tracks.performer: Strings of the Hungarian State Opera Orchestra; Tamas Benedek, conductor

soundsnips.text: Part didn't show much musical talent growing up. He began to seriously consider music as a profession only after he joined the military. He played oboe and percussion in the army band.
Part sometimes sits at a piano for hours on end and hits one key over and over until he figures out how to celebrate that one note through a composition.
Part: "I have discovered that it is enough when a single note is beautifully played. This one note, or a silent beat, or a moment of silence, comforts me."

Part created his own compositional technique called "tintinnabuli" -- an effect made by having one voice produce stepwise scalar movement while the others respond in arpeggiated triads. He uses it extensively in this piece.
Here, the violins drop out to make way for the viola -- an instrument that is a staple of string quartets, orchestral music, and chamber music.
In his youth, Part worked for Estonian Radio in Tallinn. He also produced over 50 film scores.
This piece was originally scored for four vocalists. Twelve years after Part wrote it, he re-orchestrated the piece for strings.
Part is one of the most well-documented living composers. Nearly all of his works have been recorded and are available via contemporary media.
Part is most known for pursuing a style sometimes referred to as "holy minimalism." By joining secular and religious musical techniques, he creates music that is repetitious, yet serenely spare.

tracks.title: Intermezzo in A, Op. 118, No. 2
tracks.performer: Daniel Pollack, piano

soundsnips.text: Brahms started his music career playing piano at shady waterfront bars, taverns and even brothels.
Brahms' voice was incredibly high pitched. He preferred to shout over talking at a normal volume so he could sound more gruff.
Brahms on composing: "It is not hard to compose, but it is wonderfully hard to let the superfluous notes fall under the table."

This section of the piece breaks form with the arpeggiated textures of the previous sections. This chorale-like texture can be described as "homophonic" as the notes of each voice move in rhythmic and harmonic unity.

In 1958, pianist Daniel Pollack competed in Moscow's first annual Tchaikovsky Piano Competition. A day before the event, he found out he prepared the wrong repertoire to perform. Pollack decided to perform anyway and ended up winning eighth place.
Streicher, an Austrian piano-making company, gave Brahms one of their unique pianos in 1868. Streicher pianos had an open, lighter sound than other pianos and featured a fourth (or "bassoon") pedal.
Although Brahms fell in love with more than a few gifted society women, he never committed himself to marriage and remained a bachelor until his death.

When an admirer climbed a ladder to watch the composer at work in his home, Brahms was so furious that he went outside and pushed the ladder away -- an action that almost killed the curious young man!
Brahms composed during the mid to late 19th century.
The "Three B's" of classical music are usually considered to be Bach, Beethoven and Brahms.

tracks.title: Cello Suite No. 1 in G, BWV 1007: Prelude
tracks.performer: Angel Romero, guitar

soundsnips.text: Bach's great-grandfather, father, seven uncles, and four of his five brothers were all named "Johann." (Even his sister couldn't escape the trend -- she was named "Johanna.")
Although he is now known for his compositions, Bach was famous during his lifetime mostly due to his unparalleled keyboard skills.
Bach: "If I decide to be an idiot, then I'll be an idiot on my own accord."
This piece opens with a musical idiosyncrasy known as the "tonic pedal." The "pedal" refers to the sustained bass notes while the "tonic" refers to the key in which the piece is rooted.
The Romero family (father, Celedonio, and sons Pepe, Celin and Angel) is internationally known as "the royal family of the guitar."

Those little pieces of wire on a guitar's neck are called "frets." By pressing between different frets, a guitarist changes the length of the primary vibrating component of a string to shift the pitch of the sound.
Three of Bach's works are featured on the "Voyager Golden Record," a music/culture sampler NASA shot into space for future generations (or other life forms) to enjoy.
Bach is the quintessential Baroque composer. He wrote most of his works in the first half of the 18th century.
Bach is considered the master of counterpoint, which is the relationship between two or more voices (or melodic lines) that are independent in rhythm but, when simultaneously played, create harmony.

tracks.title: Big Fish: The Journey Home
tracks.performer: Soundtrack Orchestra; Nick Ingman, conductor

soundsnips.text: Most recently, Elfman announced he will be working on a musical based on the life of famed escape artist Houdini.
During the 1970s, Elfman and his brother Richard formed the new wave band Oingo Boingo and gained a loyal cult following.
Elfman on working with Burton: "I sit here going, 'God, I'm getting paid for this? It's so much fun!' It's like too much fun to be considered work."
Here, the strings are using a technique called "tremolo" which produces a "trembling" effect by repeating notes.

Beyond classical, conductor Nick Ingman has worked on pieces that may be defined as pop (Sade, Madonna) and rock (Radiohead, Blur). He has also contributed to film scores (Shakespeare in Love, Cold Mountain).
The plucked sound of the harp is arpeggiating a chord, which means the notes are played in sequence rather than simultaneously.
The Italian word "arpeggiare" means "to play the harp," but is frequently used in non-harp contexts.
This track is from Tim Burton's film, "Big Fish" (2003).
Elfman's first movie score was for Tim Burton's "Pee-wee's Big Adventure."
Elfman is a contemporary composer. He's written extensively throughout the latter half of the 20th century and continues to compose today.
Elfman is known for his close working relationship with director Tim Burton and has worked on almost all of Burton's films.

tracks.title: Scheherazade: The Young Prince and Princess
tracks.performer: New York Philharmonic; Kurt Masur, conductor; Glenn Dicterow, violin

soundsnips.text: Rimsky-Korsakov was among a group of composers called The Mighty Handful. They produced "nationalistic" Russian music (as opposed to "Westernized" Russian music, which was gaining in popularity at the time).
Although he took piano lessons as a child, Rimsky-Korsakov didn't develop a passion for music until he entered naval college.
Rimsky-Korsakov: "In my opinion, a distinctively 'Russian music' does not exist."
Rimsky-Korsakov writes the words "cadenza" in his musical score to give the violin a solo moment. During this section of the piece, the orchestra is "tacet," which means "silent" in Latin.

While residing in the German Democratic Republic, conductor Kurt Masur played a key role in urging non-violence during the Leipzig Monday Demonstrations of 1989 (the Berlin Wall would fall later that year).
Rimsky-Korsakov uses snare drum connotations to create a marching effect in his composition, as the same kind of drums were once used to communicate on battlefields.
"Scheherazade" is based on "The Book of One Thousand and One Nights" (or "The Arabian Nights").

Rimsky-Korsakov was granted professorship at the St. Petersburg Conservatory, but he felt it was "undeserved." He accepted the position, but spent his first three years relearning compositional techniques to live up to his title.
Rimsky-Korsakov wrote the bulk of his works during the latter half of the 19th century.

Although he was not as passionate about musical nationalism as his contemporaries, Rimsky-Korsakov created music that carries a distinct Russian flavor and his operas are among the best of the Soviet repertoire.

tracks.title: Tsar Saltan: Flight of the Bumblebee
tracks.performer: Scottish National Orchestra; Neeme Jarvi, conductor

soundsnips.text: Rimsky-Korsakov was among a group of composers called "The Mighty Handful." They produced "nationalistic" Russian music (as opposed to "Westernized" Russian music, which was gaining in popularity at the time).
Although he took piano lessons as a child, Rimsky-Korsakov didn't develop a passion for music until he entered naval college.
Rimsky-Korsakov: "To orchestrate is to create, and this is something that cannot be taught."
Those sharp swells of volume are produced by the violins adjusting their bow speeds. By moving the bow progressively faster across the strings, a biting, dramatic increase in volume occurs.
The Scottish National Orchestra was dubbed the "Royal" Scottish National Orchestra by Queen Elizabeth II in 1991.
Do the strings sound a bit muffled, or somehow less vibrant? This is done by placing a small rubber device known as a "mute" on the wooden bridges of the instruments.

Rimsky-Korsakov partnered with librettist V.I. Byelsky to write "Tsar Saltan." After writing a scene, Byelsky would hand it over to Rimsky-Korsakov, who would compose the music. In that bit-by-bit fashion, the opera was formed.

This extremely popular piece is from Rimsky-Korsakov's opera, "Tsar Saltan," which is based on a Russian fairy tale. At one point in the story, a swan princess helps a lost prince find his father by transforming him into a bumblebee.
Rimsky-Korsakov wrote the bulk of his works during the latter half of the 19th century.

Although he was not as passionate about musical nationalism as his contemporaries, Rimsky-Korsakov created music that carries a distinct Russian flavor and his operas are among the best of the Soviet repertoire.

tracks.title: Musica Ricercata: Selections
tracks.performer: Pierre-Laurent Aimard, piano

soundsnips.text: Ligeti is known for his "micropolyphony" method, which means writing music that focuses on the timbre and texture of chords rather than the melody, pitch or rhythm.
Ligeti did some pretty crazy stuff. He even wrote a piece for 100 metronomes (called "Poeme symphonique").
Ligeti: "Totalitarian regimes do not like dissonances."
Hear how the melody and harmony move in rhythmic unison? This type of texture is called "homorhythmic."
Pierre-Laurent Aimard says he's committed to the avant-garde because of a "sense of duty to a chronically under-represented aspect of culture."
One way a performer can emphasize the distinction between the melody and the accompaniment is by striking the keys with varying intensities.
This track features selections (or portions) of Ligeti's full piece, "Musica ricercata."

During WWII, Ligeti was studying composition in Nazi-controlled Hungary. He was eventually placed in a labor camp from 1944 to 1945 due to his Jewish heritage. Other members of his immediate family were placed at Auschwitz. Only his mother would survive.
Ligeti composed throughout the latter half of the 20th century.
Ligeti is considered to be a pioneer of "high modernism" and avant-garde composition.

tracks.title: Gayaneh: Sabre Dance
tracks.performer: Bolshoi Symphony Orchestra

soundsnips.text: Although that it can be argued that his music is the least "modern" of his contemporaries, Khachaturian was arraigned for "formalism" under the Soviet Union's Zhdanov Doctrine in 1948 and was blacklisted for a short period of time.
Khachaturian says it all started with mom. Listening to her sing during his youth made a strong impression on the young composer. He even dedicated his first opus to her.
Khachaturian on his extremely popular "Sabre Dance": "It's like one button on my shirt, and I have many buttons."
The metal discs which are built into the frame of a tambourine are called "zils."

The Russian Bolshoi Symphony Orchestra is the oldest orchestra in its country. It's history stretches all the way back to 1776 when Catherine II (who ruled Russia from 1762 to 1796) decreed an opera orchestra of 35 musicians.

The main percussion instruments heard in the opening are the timpani, snare drum, and xylophone. The timpani accounts for the low booming sound while the snare produces a higher pitch. The faster melodic notes come from the xylophone.
Khachaturian is a Modern era composer. He wrote most of his pieces during the mid-20th century.
Khachaturian's music is known for combining elements of Eastern styles with European classical tradition. Much of his music incorporates folk instruments.

tracks.title: Holberg Suite, Op. 40: Prelude
tracks.performer: Orpheus Chamber Orchestra

soundsnips.text: Grieg's former home, "Troldhaugen," is a popular tourist attraction in Bergen, Norway. He worked from home but he didn't work inside; he preferred to write in a small hut beside his house.
While studying music in a Leipzig conservatory, Grieg contracted tuberculosis. It left him with only one functioning lung and respiratory problems he would battle for the rest of his life.
Grieg: "Artists like Bach and Beethoven erected churches and temples on the heights. I only wanted... to build dwellings for men in which they might feel happy and at home."

Both the violas and the cello create a call-and-response dialogue using the "pizzicato" (or plucked) effect. The violas go first with a descending scale melody. Soon after, the cello play the same idea in a lower register.

Instead of designating a full-time conductor, members of the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra take turns assuming the role. Their leaderless leadership is so inspiring that they have been selected to give management seminars at large corporations (such as Kraft Foods).

Grieg indicates the string on which the viola should play the 16th notes by writing "sul" (meaning "on") followed by the appropriate string name. Although the player could play the notes across two strings, noting one particular string creates a consistent tone and avoids awkward string changes.
If you notice a certain Baroque element to this Romantic era piece, you're right -- Grieg wrote this in homage to the popular dance suites that would have been popular during Holberg's life.
This piece was written in honor of Norway-born writer and philosopher Ludvig Holberg (1684 - 1754).
Grieg composed his works during the latter half of the 19th century.
Grieg is Norway's most famous composer. He attained international popularity during his lifetime and is considered a key player in late Romantic classical music.

tracks.title: Light Cavalry: Overture
tracks.performer: Detroit Symphony Orchestra; Paul Paray, conductor

soundsnips.text: Suppe was a distant relative of Gaetano Donizetti, a leading composer of opera in the early 19th century.
Although showing musical talent at a young age, Suppe received no encouragement from his dad. It was only after his father's death in 1835 that he decided to pursue a career in music.
Here, the violins, violas, and cellos combine forces to create a "string soli." Where "solo" refers to a single instrumental soloist, "soli" spotlights an entire orchestral section.
Due to his composition skills, conductor Paul Paray won the French government's prestigious "Prix De Rome" scholarship prize when he was just 18.
This brief clarinet solo marks a tempo transition from "allegro brilliante" (fast and bright) to "andantino con moto" (slower, with motion).
The subject matter of "The Light Calvary" operetta was based on political and military issues brewing in the nation of Hungary.
Suppe wrote his compositions throughout the mid-19th century.
In his day, Suppe was lauded as a brilliant composer of Austrian opera and enjoyed his success during his lifetime.

tracks.title: Short Ride in a Fast Machine
tracks.performer: San Francisco Symphony; Edo de Waart, conductor

soundsnips.text: Adams is a big believer in emotive compositions. He says he first got the idea while listening to a Wagner opera in his car. He thought to himself, "He cares."
In the 1960s, this repetitious aesthetic became fashionable among American composers -- such as John Adams -- and thus the American Minimalist school was born.
Adams: "The best American classical music is very open, very embracing."
The snare drum is creating "syncopation" -- which means it's accentuating beats or pulses that are usually not emphasized or are contrary to the primary meter of a piece.

Conductor Edo de Waart serves as the music director of the Hong Kong Philharmonic, but his family doesn't live there. Because of concerns over Hong Kong's air pollution, his wife and two small children reside in Wisconsin, U.S.
Knock, knock! Who's there? The woodblock that's who! Woodblocks are rectangular, hollow and typically made out of some sort of hard wood.
Adams says he was inspired to write this piece after riding in the passenger seat of a fast sports car.
Adams has composed throughout the latter half of the 20th century and well into the 21st.
Adams is considered an important figure in Minimalism. His operas feature contemporary events, such as natural or political disasters, and are frequently performed worldwide.

tracks.title: String Quartet No. 14 in D minor, Death and the Maiden: IV. Presto
tracks.performer: Alban Berg Quartet

soundsnips.text: Oops: In 1956, East Germany issued a set of stamps featuring a score of Schubert's music with Robert Schumann's picture.
Schubert lived fast and died young. He smoked constantly, was wildly promiscuous and died of syphilis at the age of 31.
Schubert on marriage: "Happy is he who finds a true friend. Happier still is he who finds in his own wife a true friend."
This presto movement is based on a type of Italian dance. Italian legend has it that the only way to remedy a spider bite was to dance the poison out through the "tarantella."
The founders of this quartet named it in honor of Second Viennese School composer Alban Berg to communicate their dedication to both traditional and contemporary classical music.
The final section of the piece is marked "prestissimo" meaning that it should be played even faster than the previous tempo indication (and the section's namesake), "presto."

Yes, the title of this piece may seem morbid, however, during the Romantic period of the arts, death was a common theme in entertainment. It had a mystical connotation as it was considered the sole answer to the suffering of life.
At under five feet tall and overweight, Schubert's physical stature was less than commanding . It earned him the nickname "schwammerl" which, loosely translated from German, means "tubby."
Schubert composed during the tail-end of the Classical era in the early 19th century.

Schubert is considered a master of rich, colorful "Lieder" songs -- he composed over 600 of 'em -- but he also contributed to other genres. He produced eight and a half symphonies and dozens of chamber pieces and solo piano music.

tracks.title: The Thunderer
tracks.performer: United States Marine Band; Col. Jack T. Kline, conductor

soundsnips.text: When he was 13 years old, Sousa almost ran off with a circus band. His father promptly enlisted him in the U.S. Marine Band -- and a star was born.
Sousa was one of the founding members of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers (ASCAP), a not-for-profit organization that advocates due compensation and copyrights for artists.
Sousa on the "perfect" march: "It should make a man with a wooden leg step out."
The descending line played by the winds is known as a "countermelody," or a secondary melody that plays simultaneously.
The United States Marine Band was brought into existence by President John Adams in 1798, making it America's oldest music organization.
The trumpet-like sound is that of the bugle, which relies on the "embouchure" -- or the control of facial muscles and lips -- to produce different pitches.
During WWI, Sousa volunteered to serve in the US Navy as commander of all naval bands.
To say Sousa was proud of his nation of origin would be an understatement. He referred to his main occupation not as being a composer, but a "salesman of Americanism."
Sousa composed throughout the late 19th century and into the early 20th century.
Sousa is almost synonymous with American band music. His "Stars and Stripes Forever" is the official national march of the United States.

tracks.title: String Octet in Eb, Op. 20: IV. Presto
tracks.performer: Academy Chamber Ensemble

soundsnips.text: Mendelssohn was, well, fairly boring in terms of controversy. He had a happy childhood, success in his career, and even attained wedded bliss. Sheesh.
Felix and his comparatively talented sister Fanny shared a close relationship. They even died within six months of each other and by the same cause of death: stroke.

Mendelssohn: "Ever since I began to compose, I have remained true to my starting principle: not to write a page because no matter what public, or what pretty girl, wanted it to be thus or thus; but to write solely as I myself thought best and as it gave me pleasure."

Remember how the movement began with a single cello rapidly playing eighth-notes? Listen as now the first violin plays that opening motive. This is a great example of how a simple rhythmic and melodic idea can be the basis for an entire movement.
Here, the second cello states a four-measure motive consisting of 8th-notes. The motive is then passed from instrument to instrument, which is a technique that's known as a "canon."
This piece is considered to be one the most impressive octets ever written due to its intricate use of counterpoint, complex harmonic devices and use of each instrument as its own voice.
Mendelssohn composed this octet in 1925, when he was about 16 years old.
Mendelssohn composed throughout the first half of the 19th century.

Although many characterize Mendelssohn as the quintessential Classical Romantic composer, others see him as a father of Impressionism. In any case, he is an important composer known for his colorful, energetic works.

tracks.title: 1812 Overture, Op. 49: Finale
tracks.performer: Oslo Philharmonic Orchestra; Mariss Jansons, conductor

soundsnips.text: In 1893, Tchaikovsky "officially" died of cholera. His death has always been clouded in intrigue -- some say he committed suicide because of his relationship with a duke -- but nothing can be solidly confirmed.

Tchaikovsky tried to submit himself to societal conventions and, in 1877, married an admirer of his work -- but it ended in disaster. Two months after his wedding, Tchaikovsky attempted suicide and quickly separated from his new bride.
Tchaikovsky: "Truly, there would be reasons to go mad were it not for music."
This track has been excerpted from the larger "Overture" movement. It essentially serves as the finale, however it is not a designated section of the piece.
For conductor Mariss Jansons, music direction runs in the family. His father was head of the Riga State Opera in Latvia.

The booming noise is produced by a large bass drum. Originally, Tchaikovsky wrote this part for a canon, but not all percussionists have access to such weaponry. (We think that's probably a good thing.)

In 1876, Nadezhda von Meck (widow of a railroad baron) offered Tchaikovsky financial support and constant correspondence on the condition that they never physically meet. Tchaikovsky accepted her mysterious offer and the patronage lasted for 14 years.
Tchaikovsky composed throughout the Romantic era of the mid-19th century.

As perhaps the most famous Russian composer of all time, Tchaikovsky combined Russian nationalistic tones with classical tradition. His style is known as bombastic, colorful and overwhelmed with emotion.

tracks.title: The Flowers of Froso, Op. 16, No. 2: Summer Song
tracks.performer: Norrkoping Symphony Orchestra; Michail Jurowski, conductor

soundsnips.text: Much of Peterson-Berger's work was based on natural themes: mountains, flowers, and the seasons were often his muses.
Peterson-Berger was also a successful music journalist for more than 30 years. He specialized in extremely negative articles about other people's music.
Peterson-Berger referred to his popular compositions as "shavings from a composer's workbench."
This piece has two main themes which alternate throughout the work. Here is the first: a lush string texture that is broad and romantic in character.
The Norrkoping Symphony Orchestra celebrates its 100th year in 2012.

The short notes you hear are being produced by the string section through a technique known as pizzicato. The plucked sound is similar to a guitar or harpsichord and has, in addition to a dramatic effect, a very fast decay.

Here, the second theme comes in with a major shift of texture that is livelier, playful and full of rhythmic interplay. The double bass and clarinet trade complimentary rhythmic figures to create a dialogue.
The "Flowers of Froso" pieces are incredibly popular in Northern Europe. "Summer Song" in particular is frequently taught to young, Nordic piano students.
Peterson-Berger reached the heights of his popularity during the late 19th century and continued composing through the first three decades of the 20th.
Peterson-Berger is considered one of the major contributors to the national Romantic movement in Sweden. Much of his work was adopted as a part of the country's artistic identity.

tracks.title: At Dusk
tracks.performer: Fenwick Smith, flute; Ronald Thomas, cello; Caitriona Yeats, harp

soundsnips.text: When Foote started his studies at Harvard, he intended to major in law. Instead, he ended up receiving the first M.A. degree in music ever awarded in the U.S.
On his 75th birthday, Foote said: "May the next quarter of a century be as interesting as the last."
Foote: "Good diction is good diction; bad diction is malediction."
Listen: after finishing up its brief solo, the harp's texture changes from strummed to arpeggiated chords.
The source of the strummed chords is the harp -- an instrument that's been around for millennia. Engravings depicting harps have been found on tombs dating as far back as 4000 BCE.
"At Dusk" includes harmonic innovations introduced by impressionist composer Claude Debussy.
Foote mainly supported himself by instructing -- by teaching piano students or writing extensively on music theory.
Foote's compositions are known for being ideal examples of Romantic period compositions: colorful, expressive, and formal.
Foote was a member of the "Boston Six" -- a theoretical group of late 19th/early 20th century composers who are viewed as the founders of the American classical idiom.

tracks.title: Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun
tracks.performer: Los Angeles Philharmonic; Esa-Pekka Salonen, conductor; Janet Ferguson, flute

soundsnips.text: Debussy was raised in a modest household. His mom was a seamstress and his father was a shopkeeper.
Nadezhda von Meck (Tchaikovsky's patroness) employed Debussy as her children's music teacher.
Debussy: "Works of art make rules but rules do not make works of art."
This opening flute solo -- a well-known melody to music aficionados -- returns throughout the work. Listen for it!
Finnish composer and conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen served as music director for the Los Angeles Philharmonic from 1992 to 2009. He also holds an honorary doctorate from USC.
Here, Debussy's score calls for an instrument dubbed "cymbals antique," which are also known as "crotales." Early depictions of similar cymbals date back to at least 600 BCE.
While studying at the Paris Conservatory, Debussy's experimental arrangements earned him a big, fat "F" in his composition class.
This composer was active around the turn of the 20th century, right as the Romantic era was transitioning into the Modern era.
Because of his expressive and experimental compositions, Debussy is renowned as the ultimate "impressionist" composer -- although, personally, he disliked that term.

tracks.title: Romance in F, Op. 118, No. 5
tracks.performer: Emanuel Ax, piano

soundsnips.text: Brahms started his music career playing piano at shady waterfront bars, taverns and even brothels.
Brahms' voice was incredibly high pitched, which He opted to shout over talking at a normal volume so he could sound more gruff.
Brahms: "Without craftsmanship, inspiration is a mere reed shaken in the wind."
That fluttering sound between two notes you just heard is called a "trill."
Pianist Emanuel Ax regularly performs and records with long-time duo partner and superstar cellist Yo-Yo Ma.

One can think of the piano as a mini-orchestra. Besides its multitude of colors and tones, it has the ability to accompany itself. Notice this as the texture changes from a slow chorale to a livelier tempo.
Brahms wrote this for Clara Schumann (does that last name sound familiar?). She was a distinguished pianist who, along with her husband Robert, encouraged Brahms and helped rocket him to success.
Brahms never had a "normal" relationship with a woman. Instead, he apparently relied on the kindness of escorts.
Brahms composed during the latter half of the 19th century.
The "Three B's" of classical music are usually considered to be Bach, Beethoven and Brahms.

tracks.title: Oblivian
tracks.performer: I Fiamminghi; Rudolf Werthen, conductor

soundsnips.text: In 1954, Piazzolla won a scholarship to study with Nadia Boulanger, a highly influential artist who also taught Aaron Copland and Philip Glass.
Piazzolla was a composer, a conductor and a master of the bandoneon -- a push-button, hybrid instrument of the accordion and the concertina.
Piazzolla on interviews: "Never believe what I tell journalists."

As an introduction, the string bass establishes a recurring rhythm (or "groove") while the remaining strings arpeggiate chords. This texture -- a mix of repeated rhythm and lush chords -- is the basis for the entire work.
In 1992, the Flemish government appointed chamber orchestra I Fiamminghi as a "cultural ambassador" of Flanders, which is located north of Belgium.
The violin's four strings -- G, D, A and E -- are tuned in the interval called the "perfect fifth."

In the 1960s, his works were considered so avant-garde that the Argentinean military government publically criticized him. "All the tango critics and the radio stations of Buenos Aires called me a clown, they said my music was 'paranoiac'," said Piazzolla.
Piazzolla composed throughout the latter half of the 20th century.
Piazzolla is considered one of the most important composers in the history of tango. He elevated a dance form that was once regarded as common and overly sensual into a function of high art.

tracks.title: Four Pieces for Cello and Piano, Op. 70: Schottisch
tracks.performer: Anthony Arnone, cello; Timothy Lovelace, piano

soundsnips.text: Bruch began to compose at the age of 9 and completed his first "Septet" when he was 11.
Bruch used folk music as a major source of inspiration, especially themes from Scotland, Sweden and Russia.
Bruch's gravestone reads: "Music is the language of God."

What is a Schottische, you say? It's a German dance that resembles a polka, but slowed down. The Schottische became popular in the United States during the Bohemian folk-dance craze of the mid-19th century.
Wait a second. . . did the cello just steal the piano's melody? Yes, indeed! The opening melody has been appropriated by the cello.
Bruch on Brahms: "I can absolutely no longer reconcile this cynical mocking personality with the spirit that conceived the 'Requiem.'"

Many expected Bruch to become one of the greatest composers in his day. However, he ultimately lived in the shadow of Brahms and resisted invention in his own music. He's considered only a minor master in classical music history.
Bruch is considered a Romantic era composer. He wrote the bulk of his work during the latter half of the 19th century.
If you like this, check out Bruch's First Violin Concerto Op. 26. It's a staple of the violin repertoire and one of his most popular works.

tracks.title: String Quartet No. 2: Nocturne
tracks.performer: Gothenburg Symphony Orchestra; Neeme Jarvi, conductor

soundsnips.text: In 1833, Borodin was born as the illegitimate son of an Imeretian prince and an army doctor's wife. Neither of his parents acknowledged him as a true son.
Sure, Borodin's a famous composer, but his main gig was science. He worked in the lab by day and wrote music by night!
Borodin: "Science is my work and music is my fun."

This work was originally scored for a string quartet -- two violins, a viola, and a cello. Here it's been re-orchestrated for a full orchestra, resulting in a richer, more colorful expansion of the original composition.
Gustavo Dudamel, musical director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic and Gramaphone Magazine's 2011 Artist of the Year, is dually appointed as principal conductor of the Gothenburg Symphony Orchestra.
This solo, played by the oboe, would have been originally played by the cello.
Borodin's works were adapted into "Kismet," a musical that premiered in 1953. This track provided the melody for the song "And This Is My Beloved" in the play.
This composition was featured on The Ren & Stimpy Show in episode "Son of Stimpy" -- one of its most controversial episodes.
Franz Liszt was one of Borodin's first Western admirers and they visited each other several times over the 1870s and 1880s.
Borodin composed throughout the latter half of the 19th century.

Rimsky-Korsakov was among a group of composers called The Mighty Handful. They produced "nationalistic" Russian music (as opposed to "Westernized" Russian music, which was gaining in popularity at the time).

tracks.title: Symphony No. 5: Adagietto
tracks.performer: San Francisco Symphony; Michael Tilson Thomas, conductor

soundsnips.text: In order to be appointed as director of the Vienna Opera, Mahler had to change faiths. In 1897, he converted to Catholicism.
When Mahler conducted operas, he demanded total silence from the audience. Any noise would earn the perpetrator a stern look from the conductor himself. Even a cough was unacceptable!
Mahler: "The term 'symphony' means creating a world with all the technical means available. The constantly new and changing content determines its own form."
Mahler was known for heavily annotating his scores with performance instructions. Here, the violins are instructed to play "sehr langsam" -- or, "very slowly."
Conductor Michael Tilson Thomas' grandparents founded New York's widely-acclaimed "Yiddish Theater" during the turn of the century.
The Adagietto section from Mahler's Symphony No. 5, wasn't set for a full orchestra -- rather, it showcases the string section and the harp.
Mahler completed his "Fifth Symphony" in 1902 -- the same year he would wed Alma Schindler. She was a composer, a popular socialite and twenty years Mahler's junior.
This track features the fourth movement of Mahler's Symphony No. 5, which is possibly his most famous piece.
Mahler was active as a composer in the decades surrounding the turn of the 20th century and his work reflects the transition from the Romantic era to the Modern era of classical composition.
Mahler is known for his ten large-scale, expressive symphonies. They were written to communicate his personal emotions and philosophies.

tracks.title: Serenade for Winds in Eb, Op. 7
tracks.performer: Netherlands Wind Ensemble; Edo de Waart, conductor

soundsnips.text: Rumor had it that Strauss' wife was OCD, maniacally ego-centric, and criticized her husband's music to his face.
Strauss was just 17 years old when he composed this work.
Strauss: "Never look at the trombones. You'll only encourage them."
Remember that opening theme played by the solo clarinet and horns? Well this should sound familiar -- the horn and bassoon pair up to present that familiar melody in a slightly lower register.

The Netherlands Wind Ensemble is known for an extremely eclectic repertoire -- one moment they're playing Mozart and Strauss, the next they're performing compositions by Thelonious Monk and Frank Zappa.
Here, Strauss introduces a new theme with this clarinet and horn duet.
Strauss' father was the principal horn player for the Munich Court Orchestra.

Careful! There are many composers by the name of Strauss. The two most famous are Richard Strauss (who wrote this piece) and Johann Strauss II (who was known as "the Waltz King" and wrote "The Blue Danube").
They say Strauss cooperated with the Nazis not because of political loyalty but because he thought its administration would further promote German art and music.
Strauss was an important figure for Romantic era opera. He composed during the late 19th century and early 20th century.
Strauss' most recognizable piece is "Also Sprach Zarathustra," which is otherwise known as the first minute in "2001: A Space Odyssey" by Stanley Kubrick.

tracks.title: Prelude and Fugue in A, Op. 87, No. 7
tracks.performer: Vladimir Ashkenazy, piano

soundsnips.text: In 1961, the first cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin sang a few lines from a Shostakovich composition to mission control, thus becoming the first classical music to be extra-terrestrially beamed.
In 1936, Stalin condemned Shostakovich's opera "Lady Macbeth," calling it "muddle instead of music."
Shostakovich: "If they cut off both hands, I will compose music anyway holding the pen in my teeth."

A fugue begins with a single melody known as a "fugue subject." That musical phrase is then imitated multiple times -- each called a "fugue entrance" -- either in its original form or with a slight modification.
Vladimir Ashkenazy was one of the 1960s most popular pianists. To escape limelight's glare, he took up conducting in 1970.
After hearing a performance of Bach's 48 preludes and fugues, Shostakovich was inspired to write 24 of his own.
This piece is taken from Shostakovich's "24 Preludes and Fugues." Each of the work's 24 piano pieces is dedicated to a different major or minor key of the chromatic scale.
Shostakovich joined the Communist Party in 1960, but his motives are unclear -- some consider it proof of his allegiance, others say he was blackmailed into it.
Shostakovich is considered a pioneer of classical music's Modern era. The bulk of his work was produced during the mid-20th century.
Shostakovich is known for his large-scale and complex concert pieces. He's frequently described as one of the most important symphonic composers of the 20th century.

tracks.title: Piano Concerto, No. 2: Adagio
tracks.performer: Rachmaninov: Piano Concertos Nos. 1 & 2

soundsnips.text: After composing his first symphony, Rachmaninoff suffered a nervous breakdown and had a case of composer's block so severe he resorted to hypnotism. He claimed it worked!
Russian-born Rachmaninoff became an American citizen just a few weeks before his death in 1943.
Rachmaninoff: "Music is enough for a lifetime, but a lifetime is not enough for music."
In a "concerto," the orchestra opposes a featured soloist -- here, the piano.
In 2011, pianist Leif Ove Andsnes honored Franz Liszt's 200th birthday by guest DJ-ing on National Public Radio.

Listen as the piano takes what is known as a "cadenza," which is a display of virtuosity (or extreme talent) where the soloist displays technical flare. The performer can decide whether to follow what is written or improvise his or her own. Here, pianist Leif Andsnes sticks to the page and performs the cadenza as Rachmaninoff originally intended.
This concerto was featured in Spider-Man 3.
Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 2 was the first thing he wrote after a three-year bout of depression. It is one of his most celebrated compositions.
Rachmaninoff is considered a very late Romantic composer. Most of his work was written in the early 20th century.
Rachmaninoff was a triple threat -- he was a successful composer, a virtuoso at the piano and a brilliant conductor.

tracks.title: Blue Pacific
tracks.performer: Michael Tork: Blue Pacific

soundsnips.text: In high school, Torke played the xylophone in his school's marching band. The band would later play for the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade.
Torke on inspiration: "Music is not a confession of turmoil and personal feeling."
This a musical flourish known as a "sequence," which is when a small section of the composition is repeated in a different key or over a different chord.
In 2012, Hana Chu will be graduating from the Juilliard School with a combination Bachelor's/Master's in piano performance.
Did you know that the piano is a percussion instrument? Striking a key triggers an internal hammer that strikes a corresponding string.
Blue Pacific was commissioned by the Stecher and Horowitz Foundation for its New York Piano Competition where pianists aged 16 to 21 compete for scholarship funds.
Torke composed this track while overlooking the Pacific Ocean on a cliff in southern Mexico.
Torke is a Modern era composer and continues to write through the 21st century.
Torke is a popular composer who is known for mixing standard classical techniques (particularly from the Romantic era) with styles from modern pop and jazz.

tracks.title: Flute Quartet in G, No. 2, K285a
tracks.performer: Mozart: Quartets For Flute, Violin, Viola And Cello

soundsnips.text: Mozart didn't really like the flute -- but it wasn't the kind of flute we have today. The only thing available at that time was called a "wooden transverse flute," which was difficult to play and to keep in tune.
Mozart: "In Germany, we rather like length, but after all it is better to be brief and good."

You're hearing the same thing played by different instruments -- the strings and the flute. This showcases each type of instrument's unique register (range of notes an instrument can play) and timbre (overall quality of an instrument).
When acclaimed flutist Irena Grafenauer announced her leukemia diagnosis, her Slovenian fans flooded hospitals across the country to donate bone marrow.
Mozart wrote this flute quartet by substituting a flute for one of the two violins that would traditionally form a string quartet.
Mozart liked to layer instruments -- here the flute and violin -- by having each play the same melody in different octaves.
Mozart composed all of his work during his brief, 35-year existence in the latter half of the 18th century.
Mozart is probably the most known and loved classical composer of all time. His style is regarded as the highest example of the Viennese Classical idiom.

tracks.title: Memories of the Alhambra
tracks.performer: Pepe Romero: Recuerdos de la Alhambra / Jeux Interdits / Asturias

soundsnips.text: The Nokia Tune -- quite possibly the world's most popular ringtone -- was taken from Tarrega's guitar composition, "Gran Vals."
As a child, Tarrega fell into an irrigation ditch. The whole ordeal permanently impaired his eyesight.
The piece just changed keys. The new key is major the key, whereas a minor key opened the piece.
"I have performed on guitar since I was a child prodigy," said Pepe Romero, "and now I am an old man prodigy, and I still haven't played everything I want."
The rhythmic texture you're hearing is called "tremolo," or very rapid strumming.
The modern classical guitar requires the performer to grow out and use the fingernails of his or her right hand to pluck the strings.
This composition was featured in the 2004 film "Sideways" (with Paul Giamatti).
Along with his original compositions, Tarrega wrote 120 transcriptions (or adaptations) from the works of Beethoven, Chopin and others to make more classical works available on the guitar.
Tarrega did most of his transcriptions and compositions during the very late 19th century.
Tarrega is important in the realm of Spanish guitar composers. He was also credited for reviving the guitar as a solo instrument.

tracks.title: Serenade for Guitar and Strings, Op. 50
tracks.performer: English Guitar Concertos

soundsnips.text: Over the course of his career, Arnold wrote more than 100 film scores.
When he was 24 years old, Arnold literally shot himself in the foot to get out of military service.
Arnold on negative press: "The critics have got to live, but for God's sake, why don't they let me live, too?"
Listen as the guitar plays "harmonics" -- these sounds are created by lightly touching the string. It produces higher pitched notes than the conventional, "fretted" ones.
Australian guitarist Craig Ogden is married to Claire Bradshaw, a British opera singer. They tour together frequently.
This guitar has a very quick "decay" -- the sound dies away immediately after a note is played.
Arnold composed this piece for the extremely popular British guitarist Julian Bream.

He attained considerable financial wealth during his lifetime, however money meant little to him unless he gave it away. To spread the wealth, he was known to drop large bundles of money in the street and give big tips to waiters.
This composer was active during the 20th century's Modern era of classical music.
Arnold is a master of light, lively music. His compositions are usually lyrical in quality and reflect the influences of Latin dance music and jazz.

tracks.title: Enigma Variations, No. 9: "Nimrod"
tracks.performer: Rule Britannia: Last Night of the Proms

soundsnips.text: After the death of his first wife, Elgar fell into a creative gulch for ten years. The mental block finally lifted in 1931. The 73-year-old composer fell in love at first sight -- with a violinist 40 years his junior.
Before becoming an established composer, Elgar performed regularly at a local insane asylum.
Elgar: "My idea is that there is music in the air, music all around us; the world is full of it, and you simply take as much as you require."
Think back to the quiet opening dynamic. Elgar has now instructed the performers to play louder to create dynamic range, soft to loud.
Paul Daniel got booed by a colleague at his last performance with the English National Opera.
Here, Elgar integrates the timpani into the orchestration. The percussionist rolls the mallet across the head of the drum to produce that jarring, cacophonous effect.
Over 35 years before The Beatles transformed Abby Road Studio's street into a pop-culture mecca, Elgar conducted the studio's first recording session.
This composition was featured on The Ren & Stimpy Show in episode "Bell Hops/Dog Tags." (Mark Hamill guest-voiced in that one!)
In Elgar's "Enigma Variations," each "variation" is dedicated to a significant person in the composer's life.
Elgar composed during the turn of the 20th century, right between the Romantic and Modern eras.
Elgar also wrote "Pomp and Circumstance" (you know, the introductory song to every graduation ever).

tracks.title: Barcarolle No. 1
tracks.performer: Great Pianists of the 20th Century, Vol. 27

soundsnips.text: At 16, Rorem graduated from high school and had already performed with the American Concerto Orchestra.
Beyond composing, Rorem is also a diarist and has written extensively about all aspects of his life -- from hobnobbing with the social elite to his experiences as a gay culture icon.
Rorem: "Anyone can be drunk, anyone can be in love, anyone can waste time and weep, but only I can pen my songs in the remaining years or minutes."

The barcarolle is an Italian boat song sung on Venetian gondolas. This song type uses a 6/8 meter, which creates "lilt," or swing. The two-beat swaying pulse created could be interpreted as the motion of traveling on water.
Pianist Leon Fleisher took a three-decade hiatus (from 1965 to 1995) from dual-handed piano-playing after developing a debilitating condition in his right hand.
Did you know that the piano is a percussion instrument? Striking a key triggers an internal hammer that strikes a corresponding string.

Billie Holiday made a strong impression on Rorem: "In bending a phrase, stretching a melody, delaying the beat so as to 'come in wrong' just right, she forever inuenced my approach to song writing. . ."
Rorem studied composition with Aaron Copland during the summers of 1946 and 1947 at Tanglewood, a historic music center in Lenox, Mass.
Rorem is a contemporary composer, with most of his works written during the latter half of the 20th century.
Rorem is best known as the author of nearly 400 songs -- each of which feature an expressive, yet unsentimental, style.

tracks.title: Egmont, Op. 84: Overture
tracks.performer: Beethoven: Die Ouverturen

soundsnips.text: Beethoven got progressively deaf toward the end of his life, but it only made him work harder. His compositions became even more profound as his physical health declined.

Beethoven was born into a family of musicians and his father pressured him to pursue music at a young age. His music training was so intense that there was little time for school; his spelling and arithmetic would suffer for the rest of his life.
This overture was written to accompany the play "Egmont" by Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe and would have been the musical introduction heard before the actors took the stage.
When he was a child, Claudio Abbado didn't want to grow up to become a fireman, astronaut or even the president. Once he heard Debussy's "Nocturnes" he knew -- his destiny was to become a conductor.

These horn calls are what's known as an "antecedent." The musical material sounded by the strings which follows is called a "consequent." "Antecedent and consequent" are just another way of saying "call and response."

At the time of this composition, Goethe was considered a central figure in German culture. Beethoven jumped at the chance to work with him, but the relationship would always be strained. Beethoven thought Goethe to be somewhat stuffy and pretentious.
Beethoven was active at the height of the Viennese Classical era. The bulk of his compositions were written during the decades surrounding the turn of the 19th century.
Beethoven is one of the most famous classical composers of all time. He revolutionized every genre of music that he touched, usually by making it bigger or grander than it was before.

tracks.title: Concerto Grosso in D, Op. 6, No. 4
tracks.performer: Corelli: Concerti Grossi Op.6

soundsnips.text: The term "cheapskate" doesn't even begin to describe the legend of Corelli. To save money, he'd wear his clothes until they would fall off and wouldn't go to art galleries if admission was charged.
Corelli's remains are interred in the Pantheon of Rome, Italy.

A concerto grosso is probably best understood as an orchestral concerto. While the standard concerto highlights a single instrument, the concerto grosso showcases solo potential of the orchestra and its parts.

Nicholas McGegan is an established Baroque performer and conductor, but Baroque wasn't always his passion. He was studying 20th century music in college when he happened upon a Baroque wooden flute at the home of one of his professors. From then on, he was hooked.

Here's a subtle instrumental addition. The pipe organ is serving as "continuo," which means it's playing an improvised accompaniment that is derived from a bass line. This is a typical characteristic of Baroque music.
Corelli's Concerto Grosso Op. 6 was published post-humorously and remained incredibly popular in northern Europe for almost 100 years.
Much that's known (or "known") about Corelli's life is considered either apocryphal or is highly contested among historians because of an overall lack of surviving evidence.
Corelli was active during the Baroque era and composed most of his works in the latter half of the 17th century.
Corelli set the original standard for the "sonata" and "concert grossi" compositional forms. He was also one of the finest violinists of the 17th century.

tracks.title: Our Town: Grover's Corners
tracks.performer: He Got Game: The Music of Aaron Copland (Motion Picture Soundtrack)

soundsnips.text: Beyond his compositions and conducting, Copland wrote over 60 articles and five books on music.
Igor Stravinsky on Copland: "Why call Copland a great American composer? He's a great composer."
Copland: "If a literary man puts together two words about music, one of them will be wrong."

Unless you are incredibly pitch-sensitive, you probably missed the subtle variation to the opening melody. Copland used a common tool known as "key modulation." The key center of the piece is now slightly higher than when we began.
In this track, Copland serves two roles -- both as the composer and conductor.
The very high pitched metallic notes are being produced by an instrument known as the glockenspiel. A performer strikes the instrument with mallets to produce a bell-like sound.
This track was composed for the 1940 film "Our Town," which was based on a play by Thornton Wilder.
This composition was featured in Spike Lee's basketball movie, "He Got Game."
Although most of Copland's work seems to conjure up feelings of rural Americana, he was actually born to a working-class Jewish family in Brooklyn, New York.
Copland was a Modern era composer who wrote throughout the 20th century.
Copland is one of America's most famous (and, perhaps, most beloved) composers. He won numerous awards and honorary degrees throughout his career.

tracks.title: Gates of Gold: Arrival - A View from Sea
tracks.performer: Royal Philharmonic Orchestra; Joseph Curiale, conductor

soundsnips.text: This composer's namesake nonprofit -- the Joseph Curiale Foundation -- helps provide financial assistance to poor widows and orphans in India.

In 2011, Curiale produced a cover of Coldplay's "Fix You" that combined the work of more than 40 artists. Proceeds from the project went to aid disaster relief for the 2011 earthquake and tsunami disasters in Japan.
Curiale on philanthropy: "There's something about when you make a commitment, the universe seems to give you what you need."
The momentum and primary foundation of this work is created by the strings rapidly alternating between two notes.

The Royal Philharmonic Orchestra has a rich history performing in classical music, but they regularly defy genre limitations to also play compositions by rock and pop artists (such as works by Queen and Pink Floyd).

The wave-like notes in the background are being played by the harp through a technique known as glissando. This "glide" between pitches is created by strumming successive strings in that classic, dream-inducing fashion.
This composition was inspired by the Chinese immigration during the gold rush. The Chinese symbols for California translate as "Gold Mountain."
Curiale began his career by writing music for "The Tonight Show." He was the first staff songwriter in Columbia Pictures' history.
Curiale is a contemporary composer who continues to work through the 21st century.

tracks.title: The Open Road
tracks.performer: Eos Ensemble; Jonathan Sheffer, conductor

soundsnips.text: Whenever Harrison would start a new composition, he'd come up with his own set of arbitrary "rules" to limit his seemingly boundless creativity.
Shortly before his death in 2003, Harrison finished construction of his "Harrison House Retreat" studio in Joshua Tree, Calif. It has one very unusual feature -- it's mostly made of straw!
Harrison on sustainable architecture: "America grows enough straw in one year to satisfy all of its building needs."
The high-pitched sound beneath the flute is a string harmonic. To produce this special effect, a string player lightly touches the string at key points called "nodes."
The San Francisco-based EOS Ensemble specializes in unusual repertory. Some of their past concert series' topics included "Music Composed for the 1939 World Fair" and "Minimalism and the Baroque."
A bassoon solo! Now there's something you don't hear everyday. The bassoon is sometimes thought as a weak-sounding instrument that gets lost among loud forces. Here, the bassoon stands alone.
Conductor Jonathan Sheffer also writes film scores. He's worked on the music for Aliens 3, Sphere, Interview with the Vampire and more.
Composer Lou Harrison wrote this composition on commission for American dancer and choreographer Merce Cunningham to use in a solo dance competition.
Harrison is a composer of the Modern era. Most of his compositions were written during the latter half of the 20th century.
Lou Harrison is known for his avant-garde compositions that emphasize melody and rhythm while almost shunning harmony.

tracks.title: Distant Land
tracks.performer: Royal Philharmonic Orchestra; John Rutter, conductor

soundsnips.text: At a church in Edinburgh, Scotland, Rutter regularly leads voice lessons for any interested -- free of charge.
